bibl.title: Letter from M.A. Barber to Henry Rose Carter, August 4, 1925

div1.p: Barber discusses his upcoming personal and professional plans.

div1.head: Letter from M.A. Barber to Henry Rose Carter, August 4, 1925
div1.opener:
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
Greenwood, Miss, Aug. 4, 1925.
Dr. H.R. Carter,
2122 California St. N.W.
Washington,
D.C.
My dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
I was much pleased to get your very kind letter
July 30 with the information about early malaria in the U.S.
I shall treasure this letter as a classic bit of history. And I was
most sorry to hear of your attack of illness. I hope very soon to get
better news.

Yesterday I was in Memphis and got to see Dr. Fricks,
who has just returned from Europe. S me interesting information about
conditions there. He is anxious for me to go to Italy somewhat
before the time of the meeting so that I can get to look over
some Paris green work Dr. Hackett is doing in the Campagna or near it.
So, if accommodations can be arranged, I shall sail on the 26th of this
month, some three weeks earlier than I had intended. Mrs. Barber will
go with me. Possibly I will get over to the coast of Dalmatia, where
they are doing some anti-malaria work. Then the meeting, possibly two or
three weeks leave, and back in early November-a long stay but one which
ought to be interesting. Since I will have to go so soon I may be unable to
get together-and what may be of more importance get digested,
my information on the diminution of malaria. But I have some
new work, or hope to have, on larvicides, and Dr. Fricks thought
the people would be more interested it that. I should myself prefer
giving the larvicide paper, since I should like to get more information
on the diminution of malaria problem before writing anything about it.
Your letter, however, will be none the less valuable to me. With your
permission, I may quote large parts of it./when I come to get all
together.

Dr. Fricks had learned the details of the accident to Dr. Darling
and his party. It seems that the car did not go over a cliff, just
down a steep declivity but not enough to overturn it. But the people
in the car were thrown out on the stones. Three were killed
and two hurt comparatively little, Swellengrebel was in the car but not
badly injured.

Dr. Hackett is now living in a Roman palace (or castle?)
something magnificent, but comparatively inexpensive. I doubt if we will
be there long enough to rent a castle, much as such an arrangement would
please Mrs. Barber.

If I can get to stop in Washington I shall surely look you up.
There may be a great hurry going-I hope less of one coming back.

I send my kindest regards to Miss Carter and I thank her very much
for helping with the notes which you sent me.
div1.closer: With best wishes, M. A. Barber.
